results.title: With ‘Knives Out’ Deal, Netflix Signals It’s in the Franchise Business
results.abstract: The streaming gold rush of 2017-18, when Netflix scooped up big-name television creators, now seems to have migrated to the film world.

multimedia.caption: Netflix paid about $465 million for the rights to two sequels to “Knives Out,” a 2019 box office hit starring Daniel Craig and Chris Evans.

results.title: The Oscars Are a Week Away, but How Many Will Watch?
results.abstract: TV ratings for awards shows have been in free fall, especially during the pandemic, and Hollywood doesn’t want the viewing public to toss its premier showcase into the entertainment dustbin.
results.byline: By Nicole Sperling and Brooks Barnes
org_facet: Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences

results.title: Movies Survived 2020. The Oscars Diversified. There’s More to Do.
results.abstract: At the pandemic Oscars, anything could happen. Here are the lessons from the nominations: The good, the bad and what needs fixing.

results.title: Red Carpet or Not, Film Festivals Roll On
results.abstract: Fresh leadership and veteran instincts helped keep film festivals running during the pandemic. The leaders of the major festivals speak about how.

results.title: How Anthony Hopkins Inhabits ‘The Father’
results.abstract: The director Florian Zeller narrates a sequence from his Oscar-nominated drama about a man’s descent into dementia.

results.title: ‘Minari’ Haunted Me by What It Left Out
results.abstract: The drama dares to show sympathy for an emotionally distant patriarch and his relatively powerless wife — figures familiar to this child of immigrants.

results.title: The 6 Best Speeches of Awards Season So Far
results.abstract: From a pajama-clad Jodie Foster to the teary “Minari” child star Alan S. Kim, they managed to make their acceptance speeches work from home.

results.title: Every Film in This Oscar Category Is an Underdog You Can Root for
results.abstract: Live-action shorts were once as mainstream as best picture. Now they’re treated as afterthoughts. Their history reflects the evolution of Hollywood.

results.title: Why I Fear Movies Won’t Be the Same Without the ArcLight
results.abstract: For the director Gina Prince-Bythewood, seeing her movie premiere there or just a poster for it on display was a sign that her work mattered. News of the closure hit hard.

results.title: With a New Museum, African Workers Take Control of Their Destiny
results.abstract: A Dutch artist worked with former plantation employees to create a “white cube” that they hope will one day display works returned from European museums.

results.abstract: “Is there a sincere attempt to understand the world, or is the action just one of manipulation and distraction?”

results.title: ‘Nomadland’ Wins Big at Diverse BAFTAs
results.abstract: Four awards went to Chloé Zhao’s tale of itinerant Americans, living in vans and rolling through gorgeous landscapes, seeking temporary jobs to eke out an existence.

results.title: Benita Raphan, Maker of Lyrical Short Films, Is Dead at 58
results.abstract: Her dreamlike “genius” films about figures like Emily Dickinson and Buckminster Fuller hovered between documentary and experimental cinema.

multimedia.caption: The filmmaker Benita Raphan in her New York City apartment in 1999. She was a gleaner, a friend said — an urban anthropologist who found unusual objects that often ended up in her films.
multimedia.copyright: Barbara Alper for The New York Times

results.title: Chloé Zhao Becomes Second Woman to Win Top Directors Guild Award
results.abstract: The “Nomadland” filmmaker is  the first woman of color to take the feature-film directing prize. She’s now the prohibitive front-runner for the Oscar.

results.title: A Soviet ‘Lord of the Rings’ Is Unearthed, Epic in Its Own Way
results.abstract: Tolkien fans received an unexpected gift with the rediscovery of an all-but-forgotten 1991 production. They were also left with questions, like “why is Gollum wearing a lettuce on his head?”

multimedia.caption: A screenshot from YouTube of the character Gollum as he appears in an adaptation of J.R.R. Tolkien’s “The Lord of the Rings” that was broadcast on Russian television in 1991.

results.title: Paul Ritter, British Stage, Film and TV Actor, Dies at 54
results.abstract: A familiar face to British theatergoers, he was also well known for his role as an eccentric father on the popular sitcom “Friday Night Dinner.”
